newsitem.title: GERMANY: FEATURE - Gestapo HQ documents dark days of Cologne history.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Gestapo HQ documents dark days of Cologne history.

text.p: Just a short walk from its famous twin-towered cathedral, a mighty symbol of Cologne's proud history, lies a reminder of the city's darkest days.
The building which housed the regional headquarters of the Nazis' secret police, the Gestapo, is a sobering sight.
The premises survived the Allied bombing raids that destroyed most of the centre, but their grisly history was quickly forgotten in the aftermath of World War Two.
Now the building has re-opened as a documentation centre and memorial to the victims of the Nazis' reign of terror in the Rhineland from 1933 to 1945.
The cells in the basement have been preserved, complete with chilling inscriptions from prisoners tortured by the Gestapo.
"I'm now 18 years old, pregnant and would like to see the first child from my own womb. But it won't happen. I must die," one Russian prisoner wrote on a wall.
The centre serves as a reminder to the Rhineland that Nazism was not confined to cities more readily associated with the fascist movement like Berlin, Nuremberg and Munich.
"There's a widely held view in Cologne that it wasn't so bad here, that Cologne people were laconic, liberal and always against authoritarianism," said the centre's curator Horst Matzerath.
"However, you have to recognise that what happened elsewhere also happened here. Jews were excluded, Gypsies were deported."
SECRET HISTORY
Rhinelanders generally view themselves as more irreverent than other Germans, pointing to traditions such as Cologne's huge annual carnival, where parodies of the powerful abound.

Mazerath says there is some evidence -- such as relatively poor results for the Nazis in 1933 elections that brought Hitler to power -- to back up the claim that Cologne and the Rhineland were not as keen on Nazism as other parts of Germany.
But he added: "There are things which have to be recognised as shades of difference in a system where intolerance was everywhere and from which Cologne was not excluded".
The history of the old Gestapo building reflects the city's slowness to come to terms with its Nazi past.
As one of the few structures not completely destroyed by blanket Allied bombing, it was quickly put to good use straight after the end of the war.
It was home to the Swiss consulate just a few months after the Gestapo fled the besieged city in March 1945 and then housed public administration offices for decades.
The building's history was unknown to the vast majority of the city's residents.
A small group of activists campaigned to open up the basement, where the cells were still intact, and turn the whole building into a memorial for the victims of Nazi terror.
After years of campaigning, which culminated in some activists occupying the building and locking themselves into the basement, the city finally agreed.
The cells were opened up in 1981, giving the people of Cologne a first glimpse of the past they had long denied.

Now, with the opening of a large permanent exhibition on the upper floors after more than a year of renovation work, visitors have the chance to gain a comprehensive view of life in Cologne under Hitler.
CITY UNDER THE SWASTIKA
The exhibition makes extensive use of the statements, both written and on tape, of Cologne people who remember the Nazis.
"I saw Adolf Hitler myself in Cologne in 1936. People were really taken with him and the city was like a sea of flags," one man recalls.
"He promised peace and order and, in the eyes of my parents, he brought both. You could go into the centre of Cologne again without any worries," another witness remembers.
The building was extensively renovated over the years and no plans exist of its layout in the Gestapo days.
So architects have created a new design while trying to maintain some elements, such as the ominous long corridors, which survivors remember from the old headquarters.
Photographs demonstrate how Nazism intruded on everyday life in a city few readily associate with Hitler's regime.
One picture shows soldiers marching past the cathedral with huge crowds looking on and another shows a mother pushing a baby in its pram, complete with swastika flag.
Matzerath said one of the centre's main aims was to educate Cologne's young people about a period they may be ignorant of.
"We want to show them these aren't distant subjects but things that happened in places they know and to raise their determination not to let the same thing happen again," he said.
CRIES FOR HELP
While the collection of pictures, testimonies, propaganda films and official documents is impressive, the cells best bring home the fear of Hitler's Third Reich.
The tiny prisons, measuring about 5.2 square metres, and the words on their walls document the desperation of their inhabitants, including Jews, foreigners and resistance fighters.
The cries for help -- not just words, but also pictures of objects such as hearts and faces -- were scrawled with pencils, pieces of coal, chalk, lipstick and even fingernails.
Russian, Ukrainian, French, Flemish and Polish, as well as German, are among the languages of the graffiti, which document how conditions grew increasingly grim as the war wore on.
One inscription talks of 33 prisoners being held in a single cell. Summary executions became commonplace.
"Today is March 3, 1945. Forty people were hanged. We've been here 43 days, the interrogation is coming to an end, now it's our turn for the gallows," one Russian inscription says.
"I ask those who know us to tell our comrades we died in these torture chambers."
